column1: This unlucky nestling had not long sat in this way before some boys
column2: who had brought the haymakers their dinners
column5: and immediately began to try to catch him. But though he could not fly
column7: and if he was not able to run
column8: at least he could hop; so every time one of the boys got near to him
column9: the nestling scrambled on to the next bough
column10: and thus from bough to bough all along the hedge. If the boys had only known how dreadfully frightened the poor little bird was
column11: they never could have been so cruel as to hunt him in this way. They did not know this
column13: and only thought of catching him. At last he had got to the end of the hedge
column14: and then went fluttering down upon the field with the boys after him. They soon were so close to him
column15: as he hopped and fluttered along the short grass
column16: that the poor little fellow felt their hands would presently be upon him
column17: and as a last chance of escape
column18: he crept and hid himself under a wisp of hay.
